div.p: The experimental dissolution of zircon into a zircon-undersaturated felsic melt of variable water content at high pressure in the temperature range 1,020 ~ to 1,500 ~ C provides information related to 1)the solubility of zircon, 2) the diffusion kinetics of Zr in an obsidian melt, and 3) the rate of zircon dissolution. Zirconium concentration profiles observed by electron microprobe in the obsidian glass adjacent to a large, polished zircon face provide sufficient information to calculate model diffusion coefficients. Results of dissolution experiments conducted in the virtual absence of water (< 0.2% H20 ) yield an activation energy (E) for Zr transport in a melt of M= 1.3 [where M is the cation ratio (Na + K + 2Ca)/(A1.Si)] of 97.7 +_ 2.8 kcal-mol-1, and a frequency factor (Do) ..... + 1 39o o,~u 5~o cm2-sec -1. Hydrothermal experiments provide an E=47.3_+ 1.9 kcal-mol-1 and Do=0 03 n+~176176 9 ," 0.o15 cm2-sec-1. Both of these results plot close to a previously defined diffusion compensation line for cations in obsidian. The diffusivity of Zr at 1,200 ~ C increases by a factor of 100 over the first 2% of water introduced into the melt, but subsequently rises by only a factor of five to an apparent plateau value of ~2 x 10 .9 cm2-sec -1 by ~ 6% total water content. The remarkable contrast between the wet and dry diffusivities, which limits the rate of zircon dissolution into granitic melt, indicates that a 50 gm diameter zircon crystal would dissolve in a 3 to 6% water-bearing melt at 750 ~ C in about 100 years, but would require in excess of 200 Ma to dissolve in an equivalent dry system. From this calculation we conclude that zircon dissolution proceeds geologically instantaneously in an undersaturated, water-bearing granite. Estimates of zircon solubility in the obsidian melt in the temperature range of 1,020 ~ C to 1,500 ~ C confirm and extend an existing model of zircon solubility to these higher temperatures in hydrous melts. However, this model does not well describe zircon saturation behavior in systems with less than about 2% water.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Our present understanding of the evolutionary pathways taken by magmas before their appearance at the earth's Offprint requests to: T.M. Harrison surface has been considerably enhanced by the application of techniques that employ the discriminating nature of trace elements in mineral/melt systems. A substantial proportion of the REE and U in rocks of the continental crust are concentrated in accessory minerals such as zircon, apatite, sphene, allanite and monazite, giving these phases the potential to provide considerable information regarding conditions during partial fusion events in the crust. However, to understand fully the redistribution of these elements amongst accessory phases during anatexis requires knowledge of both the stability and partition behavior of the participating minerals and elements. The importance of phase stability can be illustrated by the following examples. In the case where a REE-rich accessory phase is demonstrably insoluble in a melt of a given composition and temperature, the reallocation of that fraction of rare earths will be governed by solid state diffusion, a very inefficient mechanism of reattaining trace element equilibrium in a partially molten rock. Nonetheless, the observation of diffusion-related concentration gradients in such phases would provide both element partition and valuable kinetic information which could be translated into a temperature-time history of the partial melt. For the reverse case in which the accessory phase is not in equilibrium with the melt, it follows that this mineral would dissolve until saturation in the melt had been achieved. However, knowledge of the equilibrium condition would be irrelevant if the rate at which the accessory mineral dissolves is slow with respect to the time available for this reaction to go to completion.

Following the general approach outlined above, Watson and Harrison (1983a) have determined the saturation behavior of zircon in crustal anatectic melts as a function of both composition and temperature. However, in the absence of knowledge of the dissolution rate of zircon in felsic melts, they concluded that it would be premature to apply the saturation model to more than general geological problems.

This paper reports experimental results of the transport rate of Zr in a felsic melt with variable water contents. The argument is presented that this mechanism is often the rate-limiting step in the dissolution of zircons in crustal magmas. Knowledge gained from these experiments allows us to proceed with detailed reconstructions of granitoid source conditions based on chemical and isotopic characteristics of residual zircons.

div.head: General Approach
div.p: The generally low solubility of zircon in anatectic melts (Watson and Harrison 1983a) coupled with the extremely viscous nature of low temperature (~700-800 ~ C) felsic magmas effectively limits the rate of zircon dissolution by the speed at which zirconium is transported away from the crystal/melt interface. Our experimental approach is to simulate this natural situation by encompassing sectioned zircon slabs in a felsic melt which is itself preserved in some form of encapsulation. After high pressure heat treatment, the resulting Zr difffusion gradient in the glass is resolved by electron microprobe traverses perpendicular to the boundary of the zircon/obsidian couple.

div.head: Experimental Details
div.p: Five diffusion/dissolution experiments (ZIRDIS 1 to 5, Table 1) were run in the virtual absence of water using graphite encapsulation. A several ram-sized slab of zircon from the Mud Tank Carbonatite, Northern Territory, Australia, was polished on two sides and packed firmly into a graphite crucible with finely-ground obsidian. Our specimen of the Mud Tank zircon, a large, clear, low uranium (16 ppm) variety, was obtained from the National Museum of Victoria, Australia. Due to its low and uniformly distributed uranium concentration, concordant Pb ages, pristine cell dimensions and large crystal size, this zircon has been adopted as a standard mineral by geochronological laboratories (see Black and Gulson 1978;Gleadow 1978). The lack of accumulated radiation damage and the large, blemish free surface available, make this specimen very suitable for our purposes. The felsic glass is a crystal-free, low-zirconium obsidian from Lake County, Oregon. The major element composition of this obsidian is given in Watson and Harrison (1983a). The covered graphite capsules were run in a piston cylinder apparatus at 8 kbars, using a 3/4-inch diameter assembly consisting of NaC1 and borosilicate glass sleeves with internal filler pieces of unfired pyrophyllite, Pyrex and crushable AI203. Run temperatures were monitored using a W97Re3-W75Re25 thermocouple for run durations of between 3.75 and 27.7 h. The obsidian starting material contains about 0.2% water, but it is likely that at least some of this is lost from the melt during the runs. Fig. 1. Electron microprobe results from obsidian adjacent to an interface with a zircon crystal. Although this portion of the "blank couple" contains no Zr above the detection limit, secondary fluorescence effects cause an apparent gradient as high as 2.1 cps above background near the crystal/obsidian boundary which drops systematically away from the interface to backgrund at a distance of ~ 30 lira (1 cps ~ 800 ppm Zr). This profile was subtracted from Zr concentration gradients observed in run products prior to computation of diffusion coefficients

The remaining experiments (ZIRDIS 6 to 12) run at 1,020 ~ C, 1,200 ~ C and 1,385 ~ C were encapsulated in noble metal containers along with variable amounts of H20. Similar, though smaller, zircon/obsidian couples were prepared as before and run at 8 kbars for between 4.75 and 44.5 h. The run at 1,020~ C was sealed in a Au capsule and the higher temperatures run in Pt. Run information is summarized in Table 1.

div.head: Analysis
div.p: The distribution of Zr in the obsidian adjacent to the zircon was measured with a MAC electron microprobe, using 15 kV accelerating potential and a sample current of 0.065 ~tA. In most cases the beam was focused to a 4 gm spot, but was considerably widened to ~ 15 pm for analysis of the hydrous glasses. For ZIRDIS 1 through 8 run products, Zr L~ x-rays were collected via a PET analysing crystal which gives effective resolution of the Zr peak from adjacent signals. The remaining runs (ZIRDIS 9 to 12) were analysed using a TAP crystal, which incidently provides a much greater sensitivity than the PET crystal. Numerous on-peak traverses normal to the zircon/obsidian interface were taken, usually with a spot count time of 60 sec. Concentration information was obtained through analysis of glasses with known Zr concentrations (see Watson and Harrison 1983 a).

In anticipation of observing a secondary fluorescence effect (Heinrich 1981) close to the zircon, we prepared a "blank couple" consisting of a polished face of Mud Tank Zircon tightly bound to a polished slab of Lake County Obsidian with Pt wire. This assembly was fixed in epoxy and sectioned to provide an equivalent geometry to the unknown samples. Numerous microprobe traverses in the obsidian reveal a non-uniform count rate characterized by a value of ~ 5 counts per second (cps) at the contact which decreases systematically within about 30 gm from the zircon/obsidian boundary to a background value of ~ 2.9 cps. This distribution, shown in Fig. 1, when subtracted from the profiles obtained from the dissolution/diffusion runs, yields the zirconium concentration gradient. Virtually all of the crystal/melt couples involved a zircon surface parallel to the c axis. Analysis of the perpendicular to c face from the ZIRDIS 7 showed little indication of preferential diffusion controlled dissolution in this direction. Were zircon dissolution not rate-limited by diffusion in the melt, it is likely that the strong anisotropy of the zircon structure would lead to direction-dependent dissolution rates; e.g., etching of fission tracks (Gleadow 1978).

div.head: Diffusion results
div.p: In all twelve runs, zirconium counts significantly above background were observed in the obsidian adjacent to the zircon. Results for ZIRDIS 5, corrected for secondary fluorescense and background are shown in Fig. 2a. The profile is characteristic of diffusion as the transport mechanism and provides sufficient information for us to calculate a diffusion coefficient for zirconium in obsidian.

The likely choice for computing a diffusion coefficient from the data is a model which assumes that the boundary separating the zircon from the glass at x = 0 is fixed, and represents the zircon and obsidian as semi-infinite regions initially at some uniform and zero concentration, respectively. Our assumption of a stationary boundary is not entirely rigorous, inasmuch as the Zr present in the obsidian has become available as a result of the dissolution of the zircon. This is, however, unimportant in all cases, because the solubility of Zr in the melt is low enough that the boundary movement is extremely short with respect to the length of the diffusion profile. For example, in the case of ZIRDIS 3, the characteristic diffusion distance is on the order of 15 gm, but the boundary has moved only 0.1 gin. An underestimate of C o will lever the slope of the curve to yield a negative intercept and an overestimate of this quantity will do the reverse. The value of C o which returns a zero intercept on this plot is the zirconium solubility in the melt.

This data treatment is exemplified by the concentration profile obtained from ZIRDIS 5, shown both in original (Fig. 2a) and linearized form (Fig. 2b). A potential disadvantage of the inversion approach is that the resultant slope is preferentially levered by data in the asymptotic portion of the advancing diffusion gradient, where the signal to background ratio is the lowest. To accomodate this problem, we have assigned an uncertainty to each concentration datum based on counting statistics, inverted the difference between this value and the measured concentration using equation ( 2), and obtained an estimate of uncertainty on the transformed plot. As the data approach background, the uncertainty becomes infinitely large and the regression weighting de-emphasizes the contribution of the datum. However, by simply ignoring the concentration information that corresponds to less than 10 percent of C o, and using a constant coefficient of variation in y, we obtained excellent agreement with this technique (Fig. 2b).

The good fit of well-correlated Arrhenius relations is strong evidence that diffusion has been the mode of transport of Zr in the melt. These two diffusion laws plot close to a diffusion compensation curve defined by other elements in natural obsidian glasses and liquids (Hofmann 1980;Jambon 1982;Hart 1981).

A question that arises from observation of this profound contrast in diffusion behavior between a virtually dry and a "wet" obsidian melt relates to the nature of the transition between these two Arrhenius relationships. Does the addition of water to the dry system cause a gradual increase in diffusitity, or is there a threshold value beyond which the diffusion parameters for the water-bearing system become dominant ? Zirconimum diffusivities calculated for the six 1,200~ C runs are shown in Fig, 4 plotted against the concentration of water in the melt in weight percent. These data define a smooth, asymptotic increase from the virtually dry run (ZIRDIS 2) to the runs containing about 6% H20. The Zr diffusivity rises by a factor of about 100 over the first 2 percent water, but increases by only a factor of 5 between 2 and 6% water. Clearly, the rate of Zr transport in the melt increases in a systematic fashion that is related to the melt structure behavior during the addition of water. Recently, Stolper (1982) has proposed a model for the speciation of water in magmas to account for his observation of a near linear increase in the ratio of molecular water to hydroxyl groups with total water content. Over the first 2% total water content, the concentration of hydroxyl groups increased dramatically, indicating that most of the molecular water had combined with bridging oxygens to produce OH complexes (Jambon 1982). A consequence of this reaction is that the viscosity of the magma decreases and the transport rate of cations increases as the melt becomes less polymerized. The effect of additional water beyond about 2% was less dramatic, indicating that much of the water remains in the molecular form which does not significantly affect the structure of the melt. Our observation of a rapid increase in D between 0 and 2% (Fig. 4) followed by a gradual rise to an apparent plateau at about 2 x 10 -9 cm2-sec -1 is well explained by this model.

div.head: Dissolution of Zircon
div.p: The observation of inherited radiogenic Pb (Pb*) in zircons from granitoid rocks (e.g., Pidgeon and Aftalion 1978) tells us only that at least a portion of the source zircons have been entrained intact. For us to infer that zircon was truly insoluble in the melt requires knowledge of both the saturation behavior of zircon and the rate of zircon dissolution. Zircon saturation systematics have been well characterized by Watson and Harrison (1983 a) who developed a comprehensive solubility model that accounts for both temperature and compositional variations. Their results indicate that the maximum dissolved zirconium concentration in normal minimum-melt granitoids is at most on the order of hundreds of ppm. It is clear that given relatively static conditions in the magma, that is, residual grains are immobilized by the very vicous melt, the rate at which a zircon dissolves to saturate the liquid will be controlled by the rate at which zirconium diffuses away from the crystal/melt interface. In circumstances in which the inherited zircon is constantly brought adjacent to an undersaturated melt, for example by mechanical mixing, the rate limiting step in dissolution will be controlled by the interface kinetics. It has previously been shown by Watson (1982) that the dissolution rate of quartz, where not impeded by a saturation limit, is very rapid and suggests similar behavior for other silicates. Although this is an implausible geological scenario for zircon, it does provide a limiting case which will be useful in a later discussion.

To illustrate the significance of the diffusion results to the question of zircon dissolution, we shall consider the case of spherical zircons dissolving into a melt initially containing no zirconium. We can model this process very well using the solution of the diffusion equation for the region bounded internally by the sphere of radius r = a, together with boundary and initial conditions; C=Co, r=a, t<=O

To determine the time required for zircons of varying diameters to dissolve, we first calculated the mass of zirconium in the zircon, and then allowed diffusion to proceed until the integrated mass of zirconium in the surrounding halo is equivalent to that originally in the zircon. At this instant, the zircon is entirely dissolved. Our boundary condition does not exactly describe the natural process as the crystal will in reality grow smaller during dissolution, slightly increasing the average diffusion distance of late dissolved material, rather than remaining fixed at r= a. However, due to the low solubility of zirconium in granitoid melts and the result- ing very large diffusion distances required to support the zirconium, this simplification causes an uncertainty in our results of less than 0.01%. This calculation allows neighboring zircons to be as near as 5% of the characteristic diffusion distance, due to the radial dilution effect, without affecting results.

In our illustration we have chosen to use a melt composition identical to the example of Watson and Harrison (1983a) of a normal peraluminous granite, with M= (K + Na+2Ca)/(Si.A1)=I.3. At temperatures of 900~ and 700 ~ C, this melt becomes saturated at 480 and 50 ppm Zr, respectively. Thus, the dissolution of zircon increases with increasing temperature by two related mechanisms: the diffusivity of zirconium in the melt and the zirconium solubility. Results of these calculations for zircons with diameters of 50, 100 and 200 gm are shown in Fig. 5 for both wet and dry conditions. The enormous disparity in the time scales of dissolution between the hydrous and anhydrous cases is owed entirely to the contrast in activation energies of a factor of two. We have used identical solubilities for both conditions although, as will be discussed later, the solubility of Zr in dry melts is about a factor of two less than for melts containing >2% water making the curves in Fig. 5 minimum estimates of the time scales of zircon dissolution in water absent melts.

For reasonable peak temperatures,of granitoid melts in the range 700 ~ to 900 ~ C, the time required for dissolution of our three zircon sizes in a > 2 percent water-bearing melt varies between 14,000 years for the 200 I~m crystal at 700 ~ C to one year for the 50 gm zircon at 900 ~ C. These results indicate that for the geologically plausible situation where significant water is present in the melt and diffusion is the rate limiting step in zircon dissolution (and we have concluded that the actual surface reaction rate is probably rapid relative to diffusive transport) zircons will dissolve rapidly to buffer the melt at the saturation level imposed by the chemistry and temperature of the magma. Even if peak conditions are only achieved for short durations, zircon dissolution will respond virtually inStaneously.

Interestingly, although the concentration distribution described by equation ( 4) is very unlike that for a semiinfinite medium, the well known expression for estimating approximate diffusion distances, X=I/Dt, describes results of equation ( 4) to within ~ 30%. Thus, calculation of dissolution time for any sized zircon can be made using this equation together with knowledge of the zirconium diffusivity and zircon solubility in the melt.

div.head: Zircon Saturation
div.p: The zircon dissolution/zirconium diffusion data presented here are also, in effect, reversed saturation experiments. The apparent concentration at the zircon interface, Co, is the amount of zirconium that can be contained in the melt at the temperature of the experiment, i.e., the saturation value (Table 1). To compare these results to the solubility model of Watson and Harrison (1983 a) we have recast these data as in r~z~ .... /melt A plot of these values versus the recip-~Zr rocal absolute temperature of the experiment is shown in Fig. 6, along with the data of Watson and Harrison (1983 a) for a melt composition appropriate to Lake County Obsidian, M= 1.3. With the exception of ZIRDIS 7, which is not shown for reasons discussed later, all data for melts with water contents greater than 2% define a well-correlated line together with the saturation data of Watson and Harrison (1983a). It is not clear to us why the ZIRDIS 7 solubility estimate should be anomalously low, expecially in view of the otherwise systematic increase of Zr saturation with water content indicated by the other five 1,200 ~ C data (Table 1). The five virtually dry runs (ZIRDIS 1 to 5) define a linear array that is displayed by about a order of magnitude above the curve shown in Fig. 6, indicating solubilities of about half those in the water-bearing system. These data suggest that the solubility model proposed by Watson and Harrison (1983 a) is valid for melts that contain more than ~2 percent water. A possible, partial explanation for the remarkably low saturation value obtained from ZIRDIS 7 is that during the nearly two-day experiment, five times longer than any other experiment run in a Pt container, progressive proton loss occurred from the capsule, thereby lowering the solubility. This suggestion is supported by the fact that one of the measured diffusion gradients in ZIR-DIS 7 was anomalously short. It should be emphasized that this run was repeated with shorter duration as ZIRDIS 12, and the results of that run are in agreement with the bulk of the data. Our observation of a rapid, systematic increase in zircon solubility is consistent with the proposition of Jambon (1982) that the generation of non-bridging oxygens by reacting water with the melt will produce associated cation sites.

A final, possibly noteworthy, point concerning the zircon solubility information extracted from our present solution-rate data is that C o may vary slightly with crystallographic direction. Although this suggestion requires substantition, it appears that the _kc direction gives ~10% (relative) lower solubilities. Such a difference would be unimportant for most purposes, but is nevertheless interesting from the viewpoint of the crystal-growth theorist.

div.head: Areas of Application
div.p: Reconstruction of the evolution of granitoid bodies using isotopic and trace element techniques may be obscured by the variety and complexity of the possible processes of magma modification. An additional complication arises if residual accessory phases transfer, by entrainment, a significant proportion of the REE and Pb* from the source without interacting with the melt phase. This problem can be dealt with if several factors are known. These include the saturation behavior of the phase with respect to composition and temperature, the rate of dissolution of the phase, and the concentration in the melt of the dissolving species. In the case of zircon, which is well-documented as a significant host of HREE, Pb*, Hf and, of course, Zr, we have practically all this required information. The only apparent limitation is knowledge of the Zr concentration in the melt. This parameter can be estimated through several approaches, including whole rock Zr analysis and zircon point counting. A more reliable and time-integrated method would be to use knowledge of the partition behavior of Zr between mineral and melt in conjunction with Zr analysis of that phase to estimate the concentration fluctuations in the cooling magma. We are currently investigating the suitability of hornblende for this role in a companion study, as well as developing techniques to estimate the temperature history of the magma (e.g., Watson and Harrison 1983 b).

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The principal conclusions of this study are:

1) Diffusion coefficients calculated from zirconium gradients observed adjacent to a zircon/obsidian interface yield an activation energy (E) of 97.7 +2.8 kcal-mol-* and frequency factor (Do) -~"80 + 1,39o o~ -sso cm2-sec -* for virtually dry conditions, and E= 47.3_+ 1.9 kcal-mol-1 and D O = 0 03n+o.o3o * 9 ,, o.olscmZ-sec -for a 6% H20-bearing system. These results plot close to a previously defined diffusion compensation curve for cations in obsidian.

2) The diffusivity of Zr in obsidian melts increases by a factor of 100 over the first 2% water, but rises by only a factor of five between 2 and 6% water. This effect results from changes in melt structure in response to the reaction of water with the melt.

3) The saturation behavior of zircon in water-bearing felsic melts over the temperature interval 1,020 ~ to 1,500 ~ C is consistent with the lower temperature solubility data of Watson and Harrison (1983a). Zirconium solubility at 1,200 ~ C increases rapidly over the first few percent of water introduced into the melt with virtually dry melts having a factor of two lower saturation levels than melts containing > 2% H20.

4) The dissolution of zircon in hydrous granitoid melts undersaturated with respect to Zr is rate-limited by the diffusivity of Zr. A 50 gm diameter zircon reacting in a nominally dry felsic melt at 750 ~ C would require 200 Ma to dissolve compared to about 100 years in a wet melt. For most geologically plausible environments, the dissolution of zircon to the point of saturation in granitoid magmas can be considered essentially instantaneous.
